sub_title: PhD and MSCA ITN fellow in Earth Sciences at the VU Amsterdam
summary:
Passionate about understanding the geological complexities of the Variscan orogenic foreland basin, I specialize in both structural geology and geochemical analysis of quartz veins. 

My research delves into the origin of fluids during Variscan mountain deformation, focusing on stable isotopes (32Si, 18O, 2D) and utilizing advanced tools such as Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry (SIMS) and Cavity Ring Down Spectroscopy (CRDS). Additionally, I employ 40Ar/39Ar dating to determine the absolute age of fluid inclusions within quartz, providing valuable insights into the kinematics and geodynamics of these veins. EPMA, Raman, and microthermometry data of fluid inclusions and samples are integral to my projects. 

Furthermore, I harness the power of Drones photogrammetry to create immersive 3D models of veins' structures in outcrops. 

Passionate about advancing our understanding of geological processes, I am eager to collaborate and make significant contributions to the field.

treasury_media.title: 22.11.2019 - Pau, "24 heurs de l'innovation au centre de la Terre" - University of Montpellier - Exploration and Reservoir Team - sponsorship by TERINOV
treasury_media.description: "24 heurs de l'innovation au centre de la Terre" is one of  the geological competition carry out by Pole Avenia every year in Pau, France. I was one of the team member of University of Montpeller and I worked 24 hours non-stop for Capgemini. My case study was about how to extract methane clathrate in arctic zone without any environmental damage. We invite to get a synthethic polymers trap to use classic petroleum system.

treasury_media.title: 01/12/2019 - 68-ième Congrès de la Société l'Industrie Minérale à Montpellier
treasury_media.description:
68ième Congrès de la SIM a été réalisé au Parc Expo de Montpellier. Le but de ce congrès est de l'exposer du travaux international de l'industrie minérale chaque année, l'organisation des différents activités (sortie de terrain, explication de l'activité de l'industrie au société et ainsi donner des cours aux participants ). 
J'était l'un d'étudiant volontaire de promo Master GER à l'Université de Montpellier pour l'organisation de ce grand congrès à Montpellier.

treasury_media.title: 20.10.2019, Field study in Mas d'Alary / France
treasury_media.description:
That fieldwork is carried out by Pr. Roger Soliva and Pr. Gregory Ballas every year to deep the knowledge about fault-fracturation-fluid interaction.
Picture capture during measurements of shale gouge ratio (SGR) within the normal faults by our Montpellier 2019-2020 promotion.

treasury_media.title: 10.05.2019 - Field study in Berga, Spain
treasury_media.description: 10 days evaluation in sedimentology, stratigraphy and structural geology in Ripoll basin of South Pyrenees, with Michel Lopez, Pierre Labaume and Michel Séranne. It all started quietly on Saturday April 15 with a brief presentation of the sites we will be studying, in order to familiarize ourselves with the site. In the evening, the 3 minibuses rented for the occasion set off for the Berga inn, a nice little refuge where the food is healthy and varied (of course we will include the actors of this journey). But this was only the beginning, because the internship begins: 6000m of log to be surveyed in 3 days (that makes for studies of facies and deposit environments ...) as well as a visit to an oil mine. 6000m and a subsidence curve further, we are back on Wednesday for the visit of a salt mine with a charming Spanish guide who forbade us to take pictures in the mine, which Mr Lopez and Mr Labaume had difficulty understanding ...  (Surely the language barrier ...). The following day was dedicated to the geodynamic study of the region, with particular interest in the overlaps of Pedraforca and Vallpogona, consequences of the Pyrenean compression. The last day was reserved for the fracturing of the alveolar limestone.

profile_positions.description: FluidNet is a consortium of European Universities and Entreprise which funded by Marie Skłodowska-Curie Actions - Innovative Training Network within Horizon 2020.
profile_positions.title: Early Stage Researcher

profile_positions.description:
Timescales of fluid migration in orogenic foreland basins :

Objectives:   To constrain fluid provenance in compaction and tectonically driven veining in the Variscan foreland basin of Avalonia, NW Europe. To obtain time constraints on the timing of vein development by absolute dating of the fluid inclusions in the vein minerals quartz, and adularia.

Expected Results: The Avalonian foreland basin was formed north of the Variscan mountain chain of central western Europe. It was folded during the Variscan Orogeny. In the slates of the Rheno-hercynicum veining is well studied and fluid pressure estimates are well constrained. The water from which the basins were crystallized is likely to be derived from compaction of marine sediments during diagenesis related to folding in the basin. The time range over which this occurred is unknown, and can be potentially constrained by direct dating of the fluid phase in the FIs.

profile_positions.title: Research Assistant

profile_positions.description:
The NE fields of Lake Albert are on pre-production phase, and their geological features are well understood. However, the role of active faults on hydrocarbon retention in an active rift context is poorly known despite several amount of fluid leakages.

The objectives are the understanding of mechanism which induced fault leak points through fault surfaces. 

The results were carried out from a complex calculation of well data and a structural model. The last one allows to obtain the localization of juxtaposition spill point on reservoir, to calculate the fault throw; shale gouge ratio from extrapolation of well data; capillarity pression and buoyance pressure.

profile_positions.title: Imperial Barrel Award 2020

company.name: CNRS - Centre national de la recherche scientifique

profile_positions.description:
3D geophyisical modelling of the equatorian forearc was carried out by using the gravimetric inversion data analysis. 

Gravimetric inversion are useful to distinguish gravity anomalies by correlating the morphostructural geology of the area. The objective is based on the description of the different basement types by using geological maps of the different formations in order to produce a 3D model.

The main goal was about finding limit of oceanic and continant crust to target the best spots for oil drilling relying on the thermal stability.
